trans-unit.source: Represents a word or short phrase that can be recognized.

Using the members of the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken> class, you can specify three forms of a word: the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Display%2A> form, the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A> form, and a custom <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation%2A> for the word.
If multiple words are stored in a single <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken> object, each is treated as a different token internally and in the result.
This class represents the `token` element defined by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) [Speech Recognition Grammar Specification (SRGS) Version 1.0.](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=201761).
For information about the SRGS `token` element and details about its support by System.Speech, see [token Element](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/3a9e8d64-7bd4-4188-a6f4-dbf28ea71632).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken"></xref> class and specifies the text to be recognized.

Creates a <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken> object whose <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A> property is set initially to the value of the `text` parameter.
The text of the new <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken"></xref> class instance.
text is `null`.
text is empty.
Gets or sets the display form of the text to be spoken.

Although they typically represent the same value, the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Display%2A> form may be different than the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A> form for a word or phrase in a <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken>.

For example, the display form may be an acronym, such as "USA", while the text that will be spoken, and to which the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation%2A> applies, is "United States of America".
A representation of the token as it should be displayed.
An attempt is made to set <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Display"></xref> to `null`.
An attempt is made to assign an empty string to <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Display"></xref>.
Gets or sets the string that defines the pronunciation for the token.
Phones are letters or symbols that describe the sounds of speech.
System.Speech supports three phonetic alphabets for specifying custom pronunciations: the Universal Phone Set (UPS), the Speech API (SAPI) Phone set, and the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA).

The phones specified in <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation%2A> must match the phonetic alphabet specified in <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument.PhoneticAlphabet%2A>.
See [Lexicons and Phonetic Alphabets](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/435e3c6f-6834-4e5a-b0f6-c17b2275dc51) for more information.

The phones specified in <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation%2A> indicate how the contents of <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A> should be pronounced for successful recognition.

The speech recognition engine uses the pronunciation specified in <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation%2A> to match speech input and returns the string contained by <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A> in the recognition result.

If the phones are not space-delimited or the specified string contains an unrecognized phone, the recognition engine does not recognize the specified pronunciation as a valid pronunciation of the word contained by <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A>.

Pronunciations specified in <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation%2A> take precedence over pronunciations specified in lexicons associated with a grammar or a recognition engine.

Also, the pronunciation in the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation%2A> property applies only to the single occurrence of the word or phrase contained by <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A>.
Returns a string containing phones from the phonetic alphabet specified in <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsDocument.PhoneticAlphabet"></xref>.
An attempt is made to set <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation"></xref> to `null`.
An attempt is made to assign an empty string to <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation"></xref>.
Gets or sets the written form of the word that should be spoken.

Although they typically represent the same value, the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A> form may be different than the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Display%2A> form for a word or phrase in a <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken>.

For example, the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Display%2A> form may be an acronym, such as "USA", while the text that will be spoken, and to which the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Pronunciation%2A> applies, is "United States of America".
The default value for the <xref:System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text%2A> property is an empty stringâ€”"".
The text contained within the <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken"></xref> class instance.
An attempt is made to set <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text"></xref> to `null`.
An attempt is made to assign an empty string to <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text"></xref>.
An attempt is made to assign a string that contains a quotation mark (") to <xref href="System.Speech.Recognition.SrgsGrammar.SrgsToken.Text"></xref>.
